conclusion: The displacement of an object can be found by calculating the area under its velocity-time graph.
For Object A, the area under curve A represents its displacement. For Object B, the area under curve B represents its displacement.
The shaded region in the second image represents the difference in area under the curves of A and B.
This shaded region is the area where the velocity of object A is greater than the velocity of object B.
The shaded region starts from t = 0 and ends at t = t1.
The width of the shaded region increases from left to right as we move along the time axis.

premise: The width of the shaded region indicates the difference in velocities between objects A and B at any given time t.
conclusion: Since the width of the shaded region increases continuously from t = 0 to t = t1, it implies that the difference in velocities (and thus the rate of change of displacement) is increasing.

premise: Given that the difference in velocities is continuously increasing, the difference in displacements must also be continuously increasing over the interval 0 to t1.
conclusion: Yes, the difference in displacement between the two objects, A and B, is necessarily continuously increasing during the time interval from 0 to t1.
